TopicTitle: Is there a way to make engines produce more heat (to increase difficulty)?

Articles.Content:
I'm guessing the obvious answer would be to "Just go into the configs and lower all the engines max temps."

But if there was some other mod that's already balanced towards the normal values, then BAM. Everything would probably explode way faster than it should.

I'm guessing I know how to do it manually: change the option for heat production in the part cfg: this example is from the massive SRB, line i'm thinking of is in bold and noted with an arrow

MODULE{

name = ModuleEnginesFX

thrustVectorTransformName = thrustTransform

engineID = S1SRB

runningEffectName = running_closed

throttleLocked = True

exhaustDamage = True

ignitionThreshold = 0.1

minThrust = 0

maxThrust = 650

heatProduction = 400 //<-- The line in question.

useEngineResponseTime = True

engineAccelerationSpeed = 8.0

allowShutdown = False

fxOffset = 0, 0, 0.35

PROPELLANT

{

name = SolidFuel

ratio = 1.0

DrawGauge = True

}

atmosphereCurve

{

key = 0 250

key = 1 230

}

}

But is there a more elegant way? Is there already a ModuleManager patch that does this? If there isn't, how would I go about making one (and possibly sharing it with the community?) Would I have to enter all the values for all the engines manually as opposed to there being a nice clean way to just increase a multiplier and being done with it?

This question really popped up after I was thinking about an idea for a mod that would let you "overthrottle" to 110% or so, with greatly increased heat output. After finding nothing of the kind, I figured that it'd be mostly useless (as everything's already balanced all nicely, and you probably wouldn't ever need that extra push, unless you were coming from Eve or something).

Anyways, in short, or "How I learned to stop worrying and read the tl;dr"

  • Is there a way to make engines overheat easier WITHOUT entering everything manually? Is there some hidden multiplier I can change somewhere?
  • If not, is there a nice tutorial on ModuleManager someone could link me to? I think I understand it, but a nice "this is how you change the heat output of an engine" example would be nice.
  • and lastly, if I DO make this, what would be the best way to share it? Specifically, a hosting site everyone is okay with? I'd imagine KerbalStuff, as Curse has that delay and weird interface, but does KerbalStuff keep the stuff hosted on IT'S servers? Or does it simply fetch it from an outside source?
  • Double lastly: Is this a good idea/has it been done already and am I just wasting my time asking all this?

No need to answer ALL the questions if you don't know all the answers (or any if you don't know any of the answers)

(P.S to moderators/other staff, I wasn't sure if this should go to gameplay. However, as it broaches a variety of subjects (difficulty preferences, addon development, community, external hosting sites, etc. I just decided to default to here. Feel free to move it if this isn't the right spot.)

Thanks to all readers. I'm going to get some sleep now. Or soon. Maybe just a few more minutes...

Heat in KSP is not a rational system, it does not work in such a way that permits difficulty; part of this is because the buildup of heat is too simple, it is based exclusively on throttle level. Part of this is because the transmission of heat between parts is nonsensical and absurd.

Decreasing the heat limit of parts will just cause more frequent unavoidable explosions; and force you to run that engine at a lower throttle level Effectively all you're achieving is a reduction in the thrust rating of your engines.

*edited for word use

Edited December 8, 2014 by Greys

The MM way, you could just multiply all the heat production by 1.5:


@PART[*]:HAS[@MODULE[ModuleEnginesFX]]
{
  @MODULE[ModuleEnginesFX] {
     heatProduction *= 1.5
   }
}

Or lower the max temperature the same way.
